channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Haiti Has Big Problems and Few Solutions
item.description: A search for a solution to the crisis in Haiti is growing more urgent as gangs gain territory and thousands more flee their homes.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: A small market in the downtown of Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital. Many streets are empty as people fear gang violence.

item.title: Blast Hits Central Beirut for First Time in Weeks
item.description: The attack came as Israel’s military has been pounding an area just outside the Lebanese capital with some of the heaviest waves of bombardment in months.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents and rescuers at the site of an Israeli airstrike on Sunday in central Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Russia Bombards Power Grid in One of War’s Largest Attacks, Ukraine Says
item.description: The attack lasted hours and involved around 120 missiles and 90 drones, officials in the country said. At least nine people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Police officers in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday with a missile fragment removed by rescuers from an apartment building.

item.title: ‘No Use for Hatred’: A Village Seeks to Move On From a U.S. Massacre
item.description: The hamlet of My Lai is infamous for American war crimes, but now it holds lessons in resilience and how to let go of anger.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I survived because the Americans shooting everyone ran out of bullets,” said Nguyen Hong Mang, who was 14 when American soldiers came to his village.

item.title: Israeli Strikes in Central and Northern Gaza Kill More Than 30 People
item.description: As Israel’s military wages a renewed offensive in the northern part of the enclave, Al Bureij and Nuseirat in central Gaza came under attack.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Outside a hospital in central Gaza on Sunday, a woman mourned victims of an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Biden and Xi Meet, Delivering Messages Seemingly Intended for Trump
item.description: Donald J. Trump has promised a more aggressive approach, after the Biden administration worked to avoid open conflict with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: President Biden and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, meeting on Saturday in Lima, Peru.

item.title: At a Ukraine Maternity Clinic, Deaths From an Airstrike Shatter a Community
item.description: It was one horrific day of the war in Ukraine when a missile fell on the Adonis clinic in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: China Stabbing Kills at Least 8 People
item.description: The stabbing, in the eastern city of Wuxi, took place days after a man drove a vehicle into a crowd in southern China, killing dozens.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fu and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: The city of Wuxi, China, where the stabbing attack happened on Saturday night.

item.title: Young Gazans Reach Global Audiences With Videos of Everyday Life in War
item.description: Displaced young Palestinians are chronicling their wartime routines on TikTok and Instagram, allowing their followers abroad to see a more personal side of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Bilal Shbair

item.title: Bitter Infighting Divides Russian Opposition
item.description: Accusations of betrayal have already tarnished the movement once led by Aleksei Navalny. Now, the election of Donald J. Trump, a Putin admirer, further complicates the opposition efforts.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Infighting and accusations between Russian opposition groups seem to be threatening the legacy of government opposition that Aleksei A. Navalny had long nurtured.

item.title: Vladimir Shklyarov, Star Russian Ballet Dancer, Dies at 39
item.description: The Mariinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, which announced the death, did not say how or where he died.
item.dc:creator: Milana Mazaeva and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vladimir Shklyarov performing in “Etudes” at the City Center in New York in 2008.

item.title: South Africa Police Try Siege Tactics on Illegal Mining, Igniting Debate
item.description: The police have cut off food and water to miners for weeks in a bid to force them out of an abandoned mine. Human rights advocates and community leaders call the tactics inhumane.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A disused mine where hundreds of men accused of illegal mining are hiding in Stilfontein, South Africa, on Friday.

item.title: As Xi and Biden Meet, Trump and Uncertainty Loom Large
item.description: The two leaders will meet in Peru, where China has steadily expanded its influence in a challenge to the United States in its own region.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Mitra Taj
item.media:description: President Biden and the Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, meeting on Saturday in Lima, Peru.

item.title: North Korea Blasts Unbearable Sounds To South Korea
item.description: Relations between the neighbors have sunk to the lowest level in years. Now, Pyongyang is blaring eerie sounds across the border that villagers say is making their lives hell.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Large speakers in North Korea seen from from Ganghwa Island, Incheon City, South Korea in October. The residents of Dangsan village claim they can’t sleep due to the strange, uncomfortable and mysterious sounds from the speakers.

item.title: Barnard’s Star Finally Has a Planet, and Possibly More
item.description: For a century, exoplanet hunters have “discovered” planets around a nearby star, only to retract the claims. But the latest find is for real.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Why Trump’s Space for Deal-Making in the Middle East Has Shrunk
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s agenda in the region is not yet clear, but the geopolitical landscape has changed significantly since he was last in office.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: Smoke from an Israeli airstrike over south Beirut this week. The political landscape of the Middle East has shifted considerably since the end of last Trump administration.

item.title: Man Hiding Tarantulas, Centipedes and Ants Is Stopped From Boarding Flight
item.description: Officials in Lima, Peru, said the endangered spiders had been taken from the Amazon basin. The man was flying to South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:description: One of the tarantulas that were seized at the international airport that serves Peru’s capital, Lima.

item.title: Satisfying vs. Productive
item.description: Weekends are, ostensibly, for relaxation. But the impulse to make every moment productive can make guilt-free leisure a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Conversations With Murray Sinclair
item.description: Thoughts from the former head of Canada’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission, who was also a former senator and the first Indigenous person in Manitoba to become a judge.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tim Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Murray Sinclair at his home north of Winnipeg in 2021.

item.title: Israel Strikes Near Beirut as Two Medics Killed in South Lebanon
item.description: Israel’s bombing campaign has complicated U.S. diplomacy to stop the Israel-Hezbollah war.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke billowing south of Beirut after an Israeli strike on Saturday.

item.title: Democrats’ Message at COP29 Climate Talks: Don’t Panic
item.description: American officials are seeking to assure the world that U.S. climate action won’t end with the return of Donald Trump as president.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: The conference venue in Baku, Azerbaijan. The focus of this year’s U.N. climate summit is financing to help lower-income countries cope with global warming.

item.title: Typhoon Man-yi Pounds the Philippines With Rain and High Winds
item.description: The storm, a Category 4, regained strength on Sunday afternoon.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Residents securing a fishing boat ahead of Super Typhoon Man-yi’s arrival in Legazpi City, the Philippines, on Saturday.

item.title: Ten Newborns Die in India Hospital Fire
item.description: The deadly episode was reportedly caused by a short circuit. Hospital fires are not uncommon in India, which lags in fire preparedness and building safety.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj, Anupreeta Das and Pragati K.B.
item.media:description: A woman rushing to an emergency ward after a fire broke out in a neonatal intensive care unit at Jhansi Medical College hospital in Jhansi, India on Friday.

item.title: Biden Discusses With Allies ‘Dangerous’ Cooperation Between Russia and North Korea
item.description: The president said stronger ties with South Korea and Japan are working, but did not address whether President-elect Donald J. Trump would continue his approach when he takes office in January.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden during a meeting with the leaders of Japan and South Korea at a summit of Asian Pacific leaders in Lima, Peru, on Friday.

item.title: Iran Told U.S. That It’s Not Trying to Kill Trump
item.description: The Biden administration had warned that the United States would consider any Iranian attempt on Mr. Trump’s life to be “an act of war,” officials said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A demonstration in Tehran for Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani in 2020. U.S. officials have said that Iran sought to kill Donald J. Trump for ordering the drone strike that killed General Suleimani.

item.title: Trump Will Encounter a Very Different Middle East in His Second Term
item.description: The region has changed dramatically since the Oct. 7 attacks.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago on Thursday. The world has changed greatly since his first term.

item.title: Princess Yuriko, Oldest Member of Japan’s Imperial Family, Dies at 101
item.description: Her death reduces Japan’s rapidly dwindling imperial family to 16 people, and only 4 men, as the country faces questions about the future under a male-only succession law.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Imperial Household Agency of Japan, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Princess Yuriko of Japan in 2023, a few days before observing her 100th birthday.

item.title: Taylor Swift to Tour in Canada After Trudeau Issues Plea on Social Media
item.description: Ms. Swift is performing six shows in Toronto before heading to Vancouver, the final stop in her blockbuster Eras Tour.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Ian Willms
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Swift fans taking photos in front of the Rogers Center on the Thursday in Toronto, Canada before Ms. Swift’s sold out show.

item.title: Putin Talks With German Chancellor, Breaking Ice With the West
item.description: The hourlong call centered on what German officials said was a push to end the war in Ukraine. It was the first in two years between Mr. Putin and Chancellor Olaf Scholz
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley, Christopher F. Schuetze and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia at the Kremlin in Moscow on Thursday, in a photo released by Russian state media. Mr. Scholz called on Mr. Putin to end the war, saying that Russia had not achieved any of its goals.

item.title: A Whole New Ballgame
item.description: What soccer, a recent foray into coaching and years of writing this newsletter taught our columnist about the game, and himself.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Gaza War Strains Europe’s Efforts at Social Cohesion
item.description: Institutions meant to promote civility, from soccer to song, have come under severe stress from rising antisemitism and anti-immigrant politics.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters opposing Israel’s participation in this year’s Eurovision Song Contest in Malmo, Sweden, in May.

item.title: A Tiny Gladiator Tells of the Reach of Roman Empire Celebrity
item.description: A 2,000-year-old copper knife handle depicting a gladiator will go on display at Hadrian’s Wall, in the north of England, next year.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Nuclear Power Was Once Shunned at Climate Talks. Now, It’s a Rising Star.
item.description: Growing worldwide energy demand and other factors have shifted the calculus, but hurdles still lie ahead.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Cooling towers at the shuttered Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near Middletown, Pa., last month. One reactor will be brought back online in 2028.

item.title: Moldova Uncovers Fraudulent Scheme to Get Criminals Off Interpol Blacklist
item.description: Suspects sought on various charges, including drug trafficking, paid officials to exploit a mechanism intended to protect asylum seekers, according to Moldovan and French investigators.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andreea Campeanu for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Interpol office in Chisinau, Moldova’s capital. Prosecutors say corrupt officials working there assisted a scheme to remove fugitives from a wanted list.

item.title: Israel Pounds Area Near Beirut Amid Signs of a Widening Offensive
item.description: Israel and Hezbollah indicated they were clashing deeper inside Lebanese territory. An escalation could undermine efforts to reach a cease-fire, as Iran’s leader signaled he supported ending the war with Israel.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Residents searched for their belongings in the rubble of a destroyed apartment building after an Israeli airstrike in central Beirut, Lebanon, on Friday.

item.title: Sri Lankan Leader’s Leftist Coalition Wins Elections
item.description: The National People’s Power won a parliamentary election that will allow the country’s new president to unroll his reform agenda, including broader welfare assistance.
item.dc:creator: Pamodi Waravita
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Court Hears New York Times Case Against European Commission Over Vaccine Deal
item.description: The news outlet is pushing the Commission to release text messages that the E.U.’s top official and Pfizer exchanged as they negotiated a Covid-19 vaccine contract.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A spokeswoman for The New York Times said a lawsuit by the company raised key issues about democratic oversight in the European Union.

item.title: Engineers Discover a 132-Year-Old Message in a Bottle in a Scottish Lighthouse
item.description: Mechanical engineers inspecting a lighthouse found a surprising message: a handwritten missive from workers of another age.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Lebanese Fear That Wherever the Displaced Go, Israeli Bombs Will Follow
item.description: Tensions among multiple sects in the country have long lurked just below the surface. As hundreds of thousands flee Israeli airstrikes in the south, those strains are worsening.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of an Israeli strike in the Christian village of Aitou, northern Lebanon, in October.

item.title: Can These Ex-Hollywood Chimps Find a Place Among the Apes?
item.description: Behind the scenes at a Chicago zoo, chimpanzees who spent years entertaining humans are learning to befriend their own kind.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zachary, raised at a roadside zoo, out of the public eye at the Lincoln Park Zoo in September.

item.title: Fire in Retirement Home in Spain Leaves at Least 10 Dead
item.description: Emergency services said the blaze had broken out in the early hours of the morning. The cause was still being investigated.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Residents were evacuated from a retirement home where a fire broke out in Villafranca de Ebro, northern Spain, on Friday.

item.title: New Zealand Parliament Suspended as Maori Lawmakers Perform Haka to Protest Bill
item.description: Opposition lawmakers performed the haka during a reading of a bill that would redefine the country’s founding treaty with its Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.category: Te Pati Maori (New Zealand Political Party)
item.media:description: Māori members of the New Zealand parliament speak to the media.

item.title: Why North Korea Is Building Drones
item.description: Analysts say the low-cost weapons are attractive to Mr. Kim, who is intent on modernizing North Korea’s military.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, in a photo released by state media, which said it showed him supervising drone tests on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s provocative cabinet picks.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. campaigning with Donald J. Trump in October.

item.title: In Moscow, Trump’s Victory Is Welcomed, But Warily
item.description: Donald Trump’s re-election victory has dominated media coverage in Russia, where there is restrained optimism about the prospect for better relations.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A cardboard cutout depicting Donald J. Trump in the window of a bar in St. Petersburg, Russia, three days after he was re-elected.

item.title: Argentina Mulls Exiting Paris Climate Deal
item.description: The South American nation says it is considering withdrawing from the landmark agreement, which aims to limit carbon emissions and slow global warming.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Ana Ionova
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Javier Milei of Argentina is considering withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement, according to the country’s foreign minister.

item.title: Stress From Fireworks Killed Baby Red Panda, Zoo in Scotland Says
item.description: Camera footage showed Roxie, a three-month-old, agitated by the noise. She died shortly afterward.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

item.title: Murray Sinclair, 73, Who Reframed Indigenous Relations in Canada, Dies
item.description: He headed a commission that documented widespread abuse in Canada’s boarding schools for Indigenous children and sought to correct the history of Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tim Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Murray Sinclair in 2021. “We needed individual Canadians to understand not only were Indigenous people mistreated throughout history, but you were lied to as well,” he said.

item.title: Yiannis Boutaris, Vintner, Animal Defender and Greek Mayor, Dies at 82
item.description: A colorful figure in Thessaloniki, he tried to reconcile the city’s painful history with its Turkish and Jewish communities, and he extended a hand to his country’s foes.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yiannis Boutaris, the mayor of Thessaloniki, Greece, outside his office in 2012. He said he never thought of himself as a career politician.

item.title: Elon Musk Met With Iran’s U.N. Ambassador, Iranian Officials Say
item.description: The tech billionaire, a top adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, was reported to have discussed ways to defuse tensions between Iran and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Elon Musk after a meeting in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Dismay Over Trump’s Picks
item.description: Plus, when shopping meets gambling.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Representative Matt Gaetz.

item.title: France-Israel Soccer Match is Overshadowed by Amsterdam Attack
item.description: After the recent violence around an Israeli team’s game in Amsterdam, French leaders insisted on proceeding under security with a France-Israel match, and on showing up, themselves.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France (front row, second from the right), Prime Minister Michel Barnier (front left), and former presidents Nicolas Sarkozy and Francois Hollande (behind Mr. Macron) attended the France-Israel soccer match amid heavy security.

item.title: New York Joins a Global City Club, With a Deal on Congestion Pricing
item.description: The city will be the first in the U.S. to adopt a fee on driving in certain areas, with the aim of reducing traffic and pollution. For some other cities, that has long been the norm.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: New York City is joining many other global cities that have congestion pricing. In most, those fees have become an ordinary part of city life.

item.title: Chemist Identifies Mystery ‘Blobs’ Washing Up in Newfoundland
item.description: A researcher thinks he knows what has been coming ashore on miles of beaches. Canada’s environmental agency says it is still looking into it.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Pope Francis Wants to Save the Environment. He Can Start With a Tree.
item.description: Environmentalists have called on the pope to halt the chopping down of a tree destined for St. Peter’s Square this Christmas, but the town providing the tree says it was doomed anyway.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis appearing before crowds from the window of his office overlooking Saint Peter’s Square in December 2023.

item.title: Israel Strikes Humanitarian Zone in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said it had been targeting a loaded weapons launcher in the area, where thousands of displaced people are sheltering in a tent camp.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Nader Ibrahim

item.title: Norway Apologizes for Forced Assimilation of Sami and Other Minorities
item.description: A policy of “Norwegianization” silenced the languages of Indigenous people and forced their children into boarding schools. The long-awaited apology avoided the issue of land rights.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gathering for a reindeer sleigh ride at a Sami Easter Festival in Kautokeino, Norway, in 2018. Norway long had an official policy of suppressing Sami culture.

item.title: Israel Bombs Targets in Syria, and Keeps Up Strikes in Lebanon
item.description: The attack occurred on the same day that Israel bombed sites in the Syrian capital that the Israeli military said were affiliated with a militant group. At least 15 people were killed, Syrian state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Aaron Boxerman and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Rescuers evacuating bodies from the site of an airstrike that targeted a house in the eastern Lebanese city of Baalbek on Thursday.

item.title: Investigators Assess if Netanyahu’s Aides Forged Oct. 7 Phone Records
item.description: Aides to Benjamin Netanyahu are under investigation over accusations of leaks, record-doctoring and intimidation. The Israeli prime minister’s office denies the claims.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: The inquiry is seen as sensitive in Israel, where the question of what the prime minister knew in advance of Hamas’s invasion could prove crucial to his political future.

item.title: Typhoon Usagi Slams Into the Philippines
item.description: The storm made landfall on the island of Luzon. Forecasters warned of torrential rain and landslides in the north of the country.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A fisherman trying to secure a boat during a storm in Santa Ana, the Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A victory for the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump with President Biden, in the Oval Office yesterday.
